channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Battle for Kyiv Looms as a Long and Bloody Conflict
item.description: Ukraine’s capital is the biggest prize of all for the Russian military. If Russia tries to take control, it could lead to one of the biggest urban conflicts since World War II.

item.title: Ice Skating at a Rink Is Fun. Gliding Through a Forest? Glorious.
item.description: Ottawa’s winter-lovers can now pick among a half-dozen skating trails that wind for miles through the wilderness in and around the city. But climate change threatens the good times.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Aaron Vincent Elkaim
item.media:description: Skating through the woods at Arrowhead Provincial Park near Huntsville, Ontario.

item.title: Live Updates: Missile Strike Turns Ukrainian Marine Barracks to Rubble, Killing Dozens
item.description: Fighting moves to the center of the besieged coastal city of Mariupol. In eastern and southern Ukraine, millions have fled or are cut off from humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kyiv residents received food at a distribution site on Saturday. Despite weeks of fighting and shelling around the city, many residents have not evacuated and continue to hold out in Ukraine’s capital.

item.title: Ukraine Reminds Georgia of Its Own War With Russia
item.description: Russia invaded Georgia in 2008. To many Georgians, that means the country should stand unequivocally with Ukraine. But the government is more cautious.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valya Vanishvili

item.title: Shadows of Algerian War Loom Over Election Campaign in France
item.description: As President Emmanuel Macron addresses his country’s colonial history, echoes of that past have pervaded the messaging of right-wing candidates ahead of the voting in April.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking on Saturday at a commemoration event in Paris on the 60th anniversary of the Évian Accords, which ended the war for Algerian independence.

item.title: ‘They Keep Killing Us’: Violence Rages in Sudan’s Darfur Two Decades On
item.description: The resurgence of ethnically motivated attacks in the country’s restive western region has led to enormous displacement and a growing humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Faiz Abubakar Muhamed for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dozens of people were killed and thousands fled when gunmen stormed through Krinding Camp in West Darfur last year, burning and destroying homes.

item.title: 4 U.S. Marines Killed in Osprey Crash in Norway
item.description: The police said that the tilt-rotor aircraft, which was taking part in a NATO training exercise, crashed on Friday evening, killing all crew members aboard.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A U.S. Osprey aircraft taking part in a NATO exercise in 2018 in Norway.

item.title: For a Ukrainian Poet, Putin’s War Is All Too Familiar
item.description: Ihor Kalynets, 83, spent a lifetime resisting Soviet domination. Now, he says, he’s not going anywhere.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: Russia’s Brutality in Ukraine Has Roots in Earlier Conflicts
item.description: Its experience in a string of wars led to the conclusion that attacking civilian populations was not only acceptable but militarily sound.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: Ukrainian emergency workers at a maternity hospital damaged by shelling in Mariupol last week.

item.title: Who Killed Three Aid Workers for Doctors Without Borders in Ethiopia?
item.description: Three employees of Doctors Without Borders set out to rescue the wounded in a war zone in northern Ethiopia. Their fate shows the treacherous path for many aid workers in conflict zones.
item.dc:creator: Simon Marks and Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Pope Deplores the War in Ukraine but Not the Aggressor
item.description: Francis has raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” without mentioning President Vladimir V. Putin or Russia. Some analysts say that he risks complicating his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Francis in Vatican City in February. The pope has worked hard to forge a rapprochement between Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy.

item.title: In South Korea, a Spike in Covid Cases Meets a Collective Shrug
item.description: A country that once had one of the world’s most aggressive coronavirus policies is opting to learn to live with the virus, even in the face of a soaring infection rate.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and John Yoon
item.media:description: A crowded street in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, when the country set a daily record for coronavirus infections: 621,328.

item.title: Cambodia Convicts 19 Opposition Politicians on ‘Incitement’ Charges
item.description: Critics called the trial a “witch hunt,” and the latest effort by Prime Minister Hun Sen to eliminate the last vestiges of dissenting political voices in what was already a virtually one-party state.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tang Chhin Sothy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A prison van transporting jailed opposition members outside the Phnom Penh Municipal Court in Cambodia on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Francis Issues New Vatican Constitution
item.description: The document stipulates that baptized lay Catholics, including women, can lead departments and increases institutional efforts to protect minors.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting nuns in January after a weekly general audience at the Vatican.

item.title: Russian Rocket Attack Turns Ukrainian Marine Base to Rubble, Killing Dozens
item.description: As many as 40 marines were killed, an official said, but there were signs the toll could much be higher. At the Mykolaiv morgue, dozens of bodies were laid out in a storage area.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers, civilians and emergency workers dug through the remains of the 36th Ukrainian Naval Infantry Brigade headquarters on Saturday. Workers were still trying to recover bodies and survivors from the building, which was hit by a Russian rocket on Friday.

item.title: Spain Endorses Morocco’s Plan for Governing Western Sahara
item.description: Madrid endorsed a plan for limited autonomy for the territory in northwestern Africa, but the change in policy was denounced by independence groups and could aggravate relations with Algeria.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Fighters with the Polisario Front, which supports independence for Western Sahara, during a training exercise in the territory in October.

item.title: Malawi and 4 Nearby Countries to Begin Polio Vaccination Drives
item.description: The spread of the coronavirus interrupted routine childhood vaccinations globally, opening a door to diseases and compounding the health challenges on the African continent.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A clinic last fall in Zambia, one of five African nations preparing polio vaccination drives after a case was found in Malawi. Concerns over polio compound the challenges of fighting the coronavirus.

item.title: Deadly Strike on Ukraine Barracks Punctuates Russian Military Gains
item.description: Ukraine said it had temporarily lost contact with officials in the strategic port city of Mariupol, and a Russian rocket attack on a military site in Mykolaiv left dozens dead.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Marc Santora and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army position outside of Mykolaiv on Saturday.

item.title: Some U.S. States Reduce Daily Covid Reports
item.description: Some scientists and health experts see the possibility that the first signs of a new surge could be missed, but others say metrics like hospitalizations and wastewater monitoring have become more relevant than daily reports.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing at a drive-through site in Hagerstown, Md., last month. The rise of at-home testing means that official daily reports of cases may be less accurate.

item.title: Ukrainian Actor Pasha Lee Reportedly Killed in Combat
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ada Petriczko
item.media:description: Pasha Lee, photographed in uniform shortly before his death.

item.title: Another Covid Surge May Be Coming. Are We Ready for It?
item.description: “We’ve been wearing rose-colored glasses instead of correcting our vision,” one scientist said.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: An intensive care unit in Washington, D.C., this month. Though Covid case numbers are falling in most of the country, scientists warn that the quiet may soon give way to another surge by an Omicron subvariant, BA.2.

item.title: Putin Isn’t Yet Ready for Talks With Zelensky, Turkish Official Says
item.description: Turkey is trying to mediate between Ukraine and Russia and bring an end to the war. But a senior Turkish official said that Russia was in no hurry.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine this month in Kyiv.

item.title: Spring Returns
item.description: Some suggestions for how to spend the first week of the season.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Zelensky Pleads to Parliament for More Help. What Can Canada Offer?
item.description: The address by President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was also a reminder that Canada might indirectly benefit from the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky received several standing ovations while addressing the Canadian Parliament earlier this week.

item.title: There’s a Messaging Battle Right Now Over America’s Energy Future
item.description: Climate scientists and fossil fuel executives use the same terms when they talk about an energy transition. But they mean starkly different things.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Lisa Friedman
item.category: Yale Program on Climate Change Communication
item.media:description: One researcher called energy transition “a blank term that you can fill with your own preferred definition.”

item.title: Can Travel Be a Force for Peace? This Tour Leader Thinks So.
item.description: ‘We tend to think of travel in terms of distance, but I think travel is really a lifestyle, a state of mind,’ says Aziz Abu Sarah of Mejdi Tours, which explores both sides of longstanding conflicts in places like Belfast and Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: Paige McClanahan

item.title: Assad Visits U.A.E. in Latest Sign of Re-engagement
item.description: It was the long-shunned Syrian leader’s first trip to an Arab country since his nation’s civil war erupted in 2011.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Researchers find an ongoing commitment to pandemic behaviors. They call it ‘long social distancing.’
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:description: A field marked with ciricles for social distancing in San Francisco.

item.title: Brazil Bans Telegram Over Disinformation Concerns
item.description: The Brazilian Supreme Court has vowed to fight disinformation ahead of this year’s presidential elections. Banning the popular messaging app is its most drastic step yet.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Judge Alexandre de Moraes at the Supreme Court in Brasilia in 2018.

item.title: Russia Targets Western Ukraine as Biden Warns Xi Not to Aid Moscow
item.description: A scramble of diplomatic efforts bears little fruit as Russia intensifies its attacks, including with a bombardment into a relatively unscathed part of western Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Megan Specia and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The body of a victim during the aftermath of a strike on a residential complex in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Kyiv’s Suburbs Become Unlikely Front Line of Ukraine War
item.description: With savage artillery exchanges, the areas on the outskirts of the capital are the scenes of seesaw battles that have stalled the Russian advance for now.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Andrew E. Kramer, Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley
item.media:credit: Photograph by Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: People that were evacuated from the besieged town of Irpin arrived in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Warns China of ‘Consequences’ if It Aids Russian War
item.description: President Biden told China’s leader, Xi Jinping, there would be consequences if Beijing gave material support to Russia, implying that the United States could impose sanctions on China.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents in northwestern Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, sifting through debris and looking for salvageable belongings on Friday.

item.title: In Rare Rebuke, Chinese Denounce Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: A persistent minority of Chinese scholars, journalists and citizens is warning Beijing against the risks of supporting the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Outside the Russian Embassy in Beijing, in February.

item.title: As Diplomacy Drags On, Peace Seems Far Off in Ukraine
item.description: Western officials have little optimism that talks between Russia and Ukraine have reached a serious stage or have even confronted the most difficult issues.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The exposed side of a heavily damaged apartment building showed residents attempting to salvage belongings from their apartments in Kyiv.

item.title: In Irpin, a Last-ditch Effort to Evacuate From Russian Attacks
item.description: As fighting intensifies northwest of Kyiv, Ukraine, volunteer medics are risking their lives to try to rescue the last remaining residents in Irpin. Our cameras joined them on the three-mile journey.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Brent McDonald, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley
item.media:credit: Photograph by Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: People that were evacuated from the besieged town of Irpin arrived in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: Confusion and Chaos in Hong Kong as Leaders Fumble Virus Response
item.description: Government officials have been unable to curb an outbreak that has surpassed one million infections, leading Beijing to step up its intervention in the semiautonomous territory.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients outside a temporary triage area at the Caritas Medical Center in Hong Kong in February.

item.title: Hong Kong surpasses 1 million coronavirus cases, health officials say, amid a huge surge in deaths.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site this month, outside a Hong Kong residential building under lockdown.

item.title: Russia’s military progress slows, but it makes gains in the south and east.
item.description: Britain’s defense intelligence service said that Russian forces had “made minimal progress this week.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Josh Holder
item.media:description: A Ukrainian National guard soldier inspected a damaged Russian vehicle in Kharkiv, Ukraine, this week.

item.title: Russian Conductor Will Not Appear With New York Philharmonic
item.description: Tugan Sokhiev, who resigned from two posts after facing pressure to condemn the invasion of Ukraine, will not perform with the orchestra because of the war.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Tugan Sokhiev and the New York Philharmonic mutually decided that he would not appear starting March 31 “out of regard for the current global situation,” but that he would conduct next season.

item.title: Samoa locks down after recording a locally transmitted case.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Apia, Samoa, in September 2021.

item.title: War in Ukraine Prompts a Political Makeover in Poland
item.description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, Poland’s de facto leader and longtime scourge of E.U. unity, is portraying himself as a standard-bearer of European solidarity in defense of Ukraine and democratic values.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Jaroslaw Kaczynski, the leader of Poland’s governing party, during a meeting with President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv this week.

item.title: A ‘Killing Stone’ Broke in Japan. Is a Demon on the Loose?
item.description: The rock appears in a famous legend starring a nine-tailed fox spirit. The question now is whether the fracture was a good or bad omen.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Makiko Inoue
item.media:description: The split rock, which resides at a national park north of Tokyo, is known as Sessho-seki, or “killing stone.”

item.title: Covid and the ‘Very Liberal’
item.description: There’s a schism among Democrats. And the latest on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Returning to school after the mask mandate was lifted in New York City.

item.title: Amid War in Ukraine, I.E.A. Warns Nations of Global Energy Crisis
item.description: The International Energy Agency said countries should encourage use of mass transit and car pooling, among other things. That could also help the climate crisis.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The International Energy Agency’s report details 10 immediate steps that nations should take to conserve oil and gas, including car-free Sundays in cities, car pooling and use of trains instead of planes when possible.

item.title: How the War in Ukraine Could Slow the Sales of Electric Cars
item.description: The price of nickel, an essential ingredient in most batteries, has soared because of fear that Russian supplies could be cut off.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing and Stephen Gandel
item.media:credit: Maxim Babenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city of Norilsk, Russia, is a nickel-mining hub.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Casualties in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grieving in Kyiv yesterday.

item.title: Kids, Covid Isolation and Learning to Endure
item.description: The virus found us, and we’re doing just fine. I think.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The Howard Springs Covid quarantine center is the only one of its kind in Australia.

item.title: U.S. Says Russia Committed War Crimes, but Consequences Are Unclear
item.description: A day after President Biden’s remark, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said he agreed. Experts warned of hurdles to a successful prosecution.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents trying to salvage whatever they can after the shelling of a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: By Labeling Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ Biden Personalizes the Conflict
item.description: President Biden’s visceral reaction to the horrifying images coming out of Ukraine also reflects a broader effort to isolate the Russian leader.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden called President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia a “war criminal” on Wednesday.

item.title: Why Vladimir Putin Invokes Nazis to Justify His Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: The language of Russia’s invasion has been dominated by the word “Nazi” — a puzzling assertion about a country whose leader is Jewish.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Billboards quoting President Vladimir V. Putin in Simferopol, Crimea, this month. The one on the right reads “We want the demilitarization and denazification of Ukraine.”

item.title: Italy is planning to roll back many of its vaccine requirements.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: In Rome in February. Starting on May 1, proof of vaccination or of recent recovery from the virus will no longer be necessary to gain access to many social activities.

item.title: Survivors Emerge From a Bombed Theater, but Ukraine’s Suffering Grows
item.description: Russia continues to devastate cities and hit civilians, as Ukrainian forces strike back and peace talks drag on.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Nagourney

item.title: Canada approves the Moderna vaccine for children ages 6 to 11.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Vials of the Moderna COVID-19 vaccine are seen at Apotex pharmaceutical company in Toronto, Ontario, last April.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The Destruction of Ukraine
item.description: Plus South Korea’s new approach to the virus and Cambodia’s crackdown on opposition leaders.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tetiana Vaskovska, 58, wept as she collected family photographs from the remnants of her home in Kyiv.

item.title: House Votes to Suspend Normal Trade Relations With Russia
item.description: The bill, which still needs Senate approval, is the latest in a series of measures that lawmakers have passed to support Ukraine and punish Russia for its invasion.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: A customs officer walked past shipping containers in Kaliningrad, Russia, last year. The bill passed by the House would allow the United States to impose higher tariffs on Russian goods.

item.title: NOAA Expects Drought Conditions to Persist Through the Spring
item.description: Winter precipitation amounts were not enough to significantly improve conditions in much of the country, government scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: Lake Oroville in California last summer.

item.title: Peru’s Top Court Reinstates Pardon for Former President Alberto Fujimori
item.description: The court issued a ruling to release Mr. Fujimori from prison, where he has served less than 15 years of a 25-year sentence for committing human rights abuses. The government said it would appeal the ruling.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peruvians in downtown Lima on Thursday protested a court ruling that reinstated a pardon for Alberto Fujimori, the country’s former authoritarian president, allowing him to leave prison.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Argues for Second Term as French President
item.description: The Ukraine war has given the French leader a strong edge and few reasons to engage with his political opponents. He held a news conference to quell criticism that he is avoiding debate.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Mr. Macron speaking on Thursday in Aubervilliers, north of Paris. The news conference served as a rebuttal to rising criticism that he has not engaged in any debate or laid out an agenda.

item.title: LGBTQ Activists in Ukraine Share the Fight Against Russia’s Invasion
item.description: A pro-Russian puppet government would be less supportive of gay rights, the activists say, and incidents of discrimination would be likely to rise, as they have in Russian-backed separatist regions.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Pride Parade in Kyiv, Ukraine, last September.
